title: Control Flow in R
text:
Anonymous Functions

In Python you declare the name of a function using def
In R, you make the function without a name, then assign it to a variable:




def multiply_by_5(num):
  return num * 5
multiply_by_5(10)

50




multiply_by_5 <- function(num) {
  return(num * 5)
}
multiply_by_5(10)

[1] 50





Python also has anonymous functions, via lambda:


double_it = lambda x: x * 2
double_it(10)

20

title: Introduction to R
text:
Careful With ‚ÄúBasic‚Äù Operators Like +!

If you‚Äôre used to Python, + feels like a natural way to combine things
R forces you to think explicitly about combining (\(\neq\) adding): more restrictive +
For strings:


In Python: + means concatenate

message = "Hi" + " " + "Jeff"
print(message)

Hi Jeff



In R: + is not allowed!

my_message <- "Hi" + " " + "Jeff"

Error in "Hi" + " ": non-numeric argument to binary operator




For numeric lists‚Ä¶


In Python: + means concatenate

[1, 2] + [3, 4]

[1, 2, 3, 4]



In R: + means vector addition!

c(1,2) + c(3,4)

[1] 4 6

title: Introduction to R
section: Why Are There Two Ways to Do Everything?
text:
Why Are There Two Ways to Do Everything?

One key reason: tidyverse built on the pipe operator |>
Recognition that data science often involves pipelines: chains of operations performed in sequence

E.g., scrape data ‚Üí clean data ‚Üí save to DB

Base R approach:
result <- saveToDB(cleanData(scrapeData()))
Tidyverse approach:
result <- scrapeData() |> cleanData() |> saveToDB()
Now imagine pipelines used by giant companies, e.g., training Netflix‚Äôs recommendation engine!

section: The Inevitable Headaches of Missing Data in Python
text:
The Inevitable Headaches of Missing Data in Python


 Given a .csv with missing entries:


my_data.csv

id,name,email
0,jeff,jeff@jeff.com
1,,nobody@no.com
3,zayd,z@email.biz

 Python defaults to object columns with NaN (Not-a-Number) values

import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv("my_data.csv")
df

   id  name          email
0   0  jeff  jeff@jeff.com
1   1   NaN  nobody@no.com
2   3  zayd    z@email.biz

df.dtypes

id        int64
name     object
email    object
dtype: object



 Intuitive fix usually isn‚Äôt what you want:

df_bad = df.copy()
df_bad['name'] = df_bad['name'].astype(str)
df_bad

   id  name          email
0   0  jeff  jeff@jeff.com
1   1   nan  nobody@no.com
2   3  zayd    z@email.biz

df_bad.iloc[1]['name']

'nan'


 This alternative approach ensures missing values are empty strings

df_better = df.copy()
df_better['name'] = df_better['name'].fillna('').astype(str)
df_better

   id  name          email
0   0  jeff  jeff@jeff.com
1   1        nobody@no.com
2   3  zayd    z@email.biz

df_better.iloc[1]['name']

''

title: Introduction to R
text:
Bonus: Built-In Matrices

For data analysis (cleaning, plotting), data.frame is usually the way to go
For linear algebra (inverting, multiplying matrices)‚Ä¶


Use 2D vectors!

my_matrix <- matrix(
  data=c(1, 2, 3, 4),
  nrow=2, ncol=2, byrow=TRUE
)
my_matrix

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    2
[2,]    3    4

class(my_matrix)

[1] "matrix" "array" 



Beware! Matrix multiply operator is %*%, NOT *:

my_matrix * my_matrix

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    4
[2,]    9   16

my_matrix %*% my_matrix

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    7   10
[2,]   15   22

title: Assignment 7
text:
K-mean Clustering
Let‚Äôs create a function for K-means clustering algorithm.


Details of Above Figure
The progress of the K-means algorithm with K=3.
‚Ä¢ Top left: The observations are shown.
‚Ä¢ Top center: In Step 1 of the algorithm, each observation is randomly assigned to a cluster using some kind of a label. It could be ‚Äú1‚Äù, ‚Äú2‚Äù or ‚Äúgreen‚Äù, ‚Äúred‚Äù etc.
‚Ä¢ Top right: In Step 2(a), the cluster centroids are computed by taking the mean of each cluster assignment. These are shown as large colored disks. Initially the centroids are almost completely overlapping because the initial cluster assignments were chosen at random.
‚Ä¢ Bottom left: In Step 2(b), each observation is assigned to the nearest centroid. This is done by computing the euclidean distance between each point and each of the cluster centers. Each point is assigned to the centroid that resulted in the smallest euclidean distance.
‚Ä¢ Bottom center: Step 2(a) is once again performed, leading to new cluster centroids.
‚Ä¢ Bottom right: The results obtained after 10 iterations.
Think about:

The iterative steps for the algorithm. What is the starting point? What is the update rule for the centroids? What is the update rule for the ‚Äúassignment‚Äù of each data point to a cluster?
What data structures might you use for implementing this algorithm? DataFrames or vectors would be fine, just think about what you need to keep track of during each iteration.
Within your implementation, create a way to visualize our 2D dataset during each implementation. That is, it is helpful to visualize the cluster ‚Äúassignments‚Äù and centroids during each iteration.

Let‚Äôs first look at a simple simulated example in which there are only two real clusters in the data. We will create a dataset where the first 25 observations have a mean shift relative to the next 25 observations.

makelinear = function(N,dist, makeplot = T){
  x=matrix(rnorm(4*N),2*N,2)
  y=rep(c(2,1),c(N,N))
  x[y==1,]=x[y==1,] + dist
  if(makeplot){plot(x,col=y+3,pch=19)}
  return(list(x=x,y=y))
}
